Here is a structured extraction of key facts, metrics, entities, and actionable insights from the provided document.

Document metadata
- Title: Barriers to High Performance Communication
- Publisher/Owner: Activ8, LLC
- Copyright: © Activ8, LLC 2018
- Source influence: Based in part on linguistic viruses described in “You Are What You Say: A Harvard Doctor’s Six-Step Proven Program for Transforming Stress Through the Power of Language”
- Authors of source concept: Dr. Matthew Budd; Dr. Larry Rothstein
- Pagination shown: pages labeled - 1 - and - 2 -

Core purpose and claims
- Purpose: Describe “linguistic viruses” so readers can identify them in themselves, others, and organizational patterns; awareness is the first step to addressing them.
- Claim: These viruses repeatedly appear in workplaces and cause lost time, lowered morale, reduced effectiveness and efficiency, and impaired leadership.
- Outcome sought: Minimize occurrence and develop skills to reduce impact, thereby improving organizational effectiveness and sustaining high performance.

Key concepts and definitions
- Linguistic viruses: Recurrent conversational patterns that undermine effective communication and performance.
- Requests as the backbone of work: All organizational actions address one or more requests.
- Implicit requests: Understood from context without being explicitly stated (example: grocery checkout—tally cost, communicate amount due, bag groceries).
- Explicit requests: Required for non-routine work to prevent misunderstanding.
- Mood of requesting: The affective or interpersonal tone/context that influences how a request is received and acted upon.
- Assessments vs. assertions:
  - Assessments: Opinions or points of view.
  - Assertions: Statements of fact.
  - Errors occur when assessments are treated as facts or offered without grounding.

The eleven linguistic viruses
Note: The order does not indicate frequency or importance; these vary by person and organization.
1) Not Making Requests
2) Making Unclear Requests
3) Living With Un-communicated Expectations
4) Not Observing The Mood Of Requesting
5) Promising Even When You Aren’t Clear What Was Expected
6) Not Declining Requests
7) Breaking Promises Without Taking Care
8) Treating Assessments (Opinions or Points of View) As Assertions (Facts)
9) Speaking Assessments (Opinions) Without Rigorous Grounding
10) Not Respecting Another Person’s Assessment (Opinion or Point of View)
11) Making Fantasy Declarations

Additions and adaptations by Activ8
- Added virus: Not Respecting Another Person’s Assessment (Opinion or Point of View) as an eleventh virus observed frequently in organizations.
- Adjusted names: Some virus names have been refined to reflect organizational observations.

Impacts described
- Negative impacts: Lost time, lowered morale, reduced effectiveness and efficiency, impaired leadership, weakened “powerful conversations” needed for high performance.
- Positive potential: Minimizing viruses and building related skills improves organizational effectiveness.

Structure/grouping noted
- Viruses 1–3 are grouped as “Ineffective Requests” (issues in making requests clearly and explicitly).

Below are strategic takeaways and business implications drawn from the “Eleven Linguistic Viruses” framework.

Strategic themes
- Coordination as a core performance lever: The framework reframes “communication” as the operating system for coordination (requests, promises, assessments), directly tied to speed, quality, and trust. It turns soft-skill gaps into hard performance constraints.
- Standardizing language to standardize execution: Creating a common vocabulary (requests, promises, assessments vs. assertions, grounding) enables cross-functional alignment and repeatable execution.
- Accountability and psychological safety as dual requirements: Viruses around declining requests, breaking promises “without taking care,” and not respecting assessments signal that performance and safety rise together when norms make declines and renegotiations acceptable and evidence required.
- Decision quality and bias reduction: Distinguishing assessments from assertions and demanding grounding elevates analytical rigor and reduces politicized decision-making.
- Strategy-to-execution gap: “Fantasy declarations” explain why aspirational goals fail. The remedy is credible commitments and explicit request/offer loops with due dates and owners.

Competitive advantages (if you are Activ8 or adopting the framework)
- Differentiated IP: Clear, memorable taxonomy; an “11th virus” inferred from field work signals practitioner-led evolution. Easier to teach, diagnose, and scale compared to generic “communication skills.”
- Measurability: The model lends itself to observable, trackable behaviors (clarity of requests, acceptance/decline rates, promise reliability), enabling ROI proofs that many soft-skill programs lack.
- Crosswalk with modern operating models: Maps cleanly into Agile/OKRs, service-level agreements, RACI, and psychological safety practices, enabling insertion into existing workflows rather than standalone training.
- Culture-plus-operations integration: Simultaneously addresses norms (mood of requesting, respect for assessments) and mechanics (explicit requests/promises), appealing to COOs and CHROs.

Market opportunities
- Hybrid/remote and global teams: High coordination costs, asynchronous workflows, and cultural nuance increase the cost of unclear requests and ungrounded assessments.
- Regulated and safety-critical industries: Healthcare, aviation, energy, pharma, and financial services gain from reduced errors and improved handoffs.
- High-change environments: M&A integrations, hypergrowth startups, product transformations, and enterprise Agile rollouts suffer from “fantasy declarations” and low promise reliability.
- Customer-facing operations: Contact centers, professional services, construction/engineering, logistics—where missed commitments directly hit NPS, revenue, and liability.
- DEI and leadership pipelines: Virus 10 (not respecting others’ assessments) and Virus 4 (mood of requesting) intersect with inclusion, psychological safety, and distributed leadership.

Business model insights and productization
- Diagnostic and benchmarking
  - Create a “Linguistic Virus Audit” that scores teams on request clarity, acceptance/decline behavior, promise reliability, grounding of assessments, and repair behaviors when promises break.
  - Offer org-wide benchmarks and dashboards tied to KPIs (cycle time, rework, escalation rate, employee eNPS, customer NPS).
- Training and enablement
  -

Below is a practical, field-ready implementation guide to identify, reduce, and prevent the eleven “linguistic viruses” in day-to-day work. It includes a phased rollout plan, concrete tools, scripts, checklists, and operating rhythms.

Goals
- Make clean requests and clean commitments.
- Improve promise reliability and reduce rework.
- Increase speed of coordination and trust.

Phase 0: Executive alignment and sponsorship (2 weeks)
- Define why now: link to 2–3 business outcomes (e.g., faster project cycle time, fewer escalations).
- Assign a sponsor and a cross-functional core team (Ops, HR/L&D, 1–2 line leaders).
- Select a pilot scope (one business unit or program).

Phase 1: Baseline and diagnostics (2–3 weeks)
1) Conversation audit
- Pull 2–4 weeks of representative artifacts: emails, tickets, chat threads, meeting notes, decision logs.
- Tag each item with these markers:
  - Is there a clear request?
  - Is there a clear promise?
  - Conditions of satisfaction present?
  - By-when?
  - Evidence given for opinions?
  - Mood and tone conducive to requesting?
  - Declines used when appropriate?
  - Changes to promises handled with care?
- Calculate simple baselines:
  - % requests that are explicit and clear
  - Promise reliability rate = promises kept / total promises due
  - % requests with by-when + conditions of satisfaction
  - % opinions labeled and grounded
  - # of renegotiations started before the due date

2) Quick pulse survey (5 minutes, anonymous)
- I know how to make a clear request in this org. (1–5)
- My team can decline requests without negative consequences. (1–5)
- We keep promises or renegotiate early. (1–5)
- We distinguish opinions from facts. (1–5)
- Our meetings end with clear owners and by-whens. (1–5)

3) Select 2–3 high-impact viruses to tackle first based on data. Typical starting set:
- Virus 2: Making Unclear Requests
- Virus 5: Promising When Unclear
- Virus 7: Breaking Promises Without Taking Care

Phase 2: Standards and tools (2–3 weeks)
Publish lightweight, org-wide standards and provide ready-to-use tools. Embed in your existing systems (email templates, ticket forms, Slack/Teams shortcuts, Confluence pages).

Core standards for coordination
- A request is not complete unless it includes: the customer, a clear action, conditions of satisfaction, due date, and a required response-by date.
- A promise is not valid unless the receiver explicitly accepts, with the same elements.
- Declines are legitimate; counteroffers are encouraged.
- If a promise is at risk, notify early and take care.
- Opinions must be labeled and grounded.

Tools and templates
1) Request Builder template (copy/paste or form)
- To [named owner]:
- Request: [specific action]
- Why it matters: [impact or purpose

Executive synthesis: Treat these 11 “linguistic viruses” as failure modes in the organization’s commitment system. Work does not flow from plans; it flows through conversations that create, manage, and complete commitments. These viruses degrade trust, create avoidable rework, and slow cycle time. The transformational move is to install a commitment-based operating system that makes speech acts explicit, instrumented, and coached—without becoming bureaucratic
